metadata.preacher: Not explicitly named (Rector of Grace Church, NYC)
metadata.sermon_start_end: This winter we had our basement waterproofed. The man whom we hired to do this job was proud of the fact that he had done similar work in some of the local churches. [...] has turned his face to us and, beholding us ungodly offenders through the eyes of his beloved Son, has said to us, 'Your faith is reckoned to you as righteousness.' AMEN.
metadata.liturgical_context: The Second Sunday in Lent, March 11, 1990
metadata.historical_context: Delivered in 1990 in New York City. Mentions the contemporary scandal of Father Bruce Ritter and the upcoming capital fund drive at Grace Church.
metadata.notes: The sermon bridges deep Pauline theology with the practical life of a Manhattan parish.

criterion_a1_imagery.analysis: The sermon utilizes concrete, everyday imagery to ground abstract theological concepts. The opening image of the 'basement waterproofing' serves as a strong, sensory entry point, connecting the mundane with the spiritual. However, as the sermon progresses, the imagery becomes increasingly conceptual. While the 'gold cross' and 'engraved word' provide a tactile focal point, the middle section relies heavily on abstract nouns like 'righteousness' and 'justification.' The 'cinematic' quality advocated by Paul Scott Wilson is present in the beginning but fades into a more didactic, teacher-like mode. The imagery is effective but not consistently 'living' throughout the entire text.
quotes: This winter we had our basement waterproofed.
God is able to raise up children to Abraham from these stones.
On the back of the cross there was one word, engraved, in Greek—logizomai.
strengths: Strong opening with a relatable, sensory anecdote.
Effective use of a physical object (the cross) as a mnemonic for grace.
improvement_points: Translate the abstract concept of 'reckoning' into more visual metaphors beyond accounting.
Vividly paint the 'Federal Buildings' to be restored to make the capital drive feel less administrative.
Use more sensory language when describing the 'new life' mentioned in the conclusion.
criterion_a1_imagery.show_vs_tell_balance: The sermon starts by 'showing' through the basement story but moves primarily to 'telling' the mechanics of Pauline theology.

criterion_a2_carefulness_and_precision.analysis: The preacher exhibits high stewardship of language, consistent with McEntyre’s principles. There is a deliberate effort to deconstruct 'Canaanite' jargon like 'righteousness' by placing it in the context of human relationships and accounting. The distinction between 'call' and 'promise' is handled with surgical precision. The language is sober, clear, and avoids the 'religious kitsch' of vague sentimentality. The preacher is careful to define terms, such as the Southern vs. Pauline use of 'reckon,' ensuring the congregation is not lost in linguistic ambiguity. This precision serves the theological weight of the message.
quotes: Paul was struck by the fact that it was not only a call, but also a promise, and that the promise was unconditional.
I use the term 'dead wrong' advisedly.
He uses it the way an accountant would use it if he were going to 'reckon' up a column of figures.
strengths: Excellent linguistic analysis of 'logizomai' made accessible for a lay audience.
Nuanced handling of the 'Father Ritter' scandal without being sensationalist.
Clear, economical sentence structure that favors clarity over decoration.
improvement_points: The transition to the capital fund drive uses slightly more 'church-speak' (e.g., 'providence for his ministry').
Could further simplify the term 'unilateral' which appears twice.
Ensure the distinction between 'faith' and 'works' doesn't fall into repetitive binary phrasing.
criterion_a2_carefulness_and_precision.jargon_analysis: Theological jargon is present but systematically unpacked and 're-homed' in common experience.

criterion_a3_musicality_and_rhythm.analysis: The rhythm is that of a steady, conversational teaching. It lacks the poetic cadence of a high-rhetorical style but possesses a 'sober beauty' typical of the Reformed tradition. There is a effective use of repetition (the word 'reckon' and 'logizomai' act as a rhythmic refrain). The sentence length is varied, though it leans toward a staccato, declarative style that emphasizes clarity over flow. It is very much 'oral language'—it sounds like a person talking to friends—but it rarely rises to the level of the 'musical' or the 'lyrical' that Grözinger describes.
quotes: He just said, 'I will bless you.' Period.
In this word—logizomai—lies my deliverance, and yours.
The world does not need to see any more badness. The world needs to see goodness.
strengths: The conversational tone creates a sense of intimacy and trust.
Effective use of the 'Period' after a short sentence to create emphasis.
The rhythmic repetition of the Greek term creates a liturgical 'hook'.
improvement_points: Incorporate more parallelism or alliteration to make key theological points more memorable.
Soften the transition between the theological exposition and the parish business (capital drive) to maintain rhythmic flow.
Use more 'legato' phrasing in the final prayer to elevate the aesthetic tone.
criterion_a3_musicality_and_rhythm.paper_language_diagnosis: Distinctly oral language; it is written for the ear, not the eye.

domain_a_poetics_of_language.summary_language: The language is characterized by a 'sober-Reformed' aesthetic. It prioritizes precision and clarity (Stewardship of Language) over poetic flourish. The imagery is strongest at the beginning but becomes more conceptual as the theological argument tightens. The preacher successfully avoids religious jargon by grounding the Greek 'logizomai' in the mundane world of accounting and Southern colloquialisms. While not 'musical' in a lyrical sense, the rhythm is steady and conversational, making it highly accessible and authentic.

criterion_b1_narrative_arc.analysis: The sermon follows a clear 'Homiletical Plot' as described by Lowry. It begins by upsetting the equilibrium: the common assumption that some people are 'closer to God' than others. This creates a tension that the hearer feels (the 'trouble'). The movement through the life of Abraham serves as the 'complication,' leading to the 'climax' or turning point: the realization that 'reckoning' is a gift to the ungodly, not a reward for the holy. The resolution is then applied to the specific life of the parish. The arc is well-constructed, though the shift to the capital fund drive feels like a secondary plot that slightly distracts from the primary theological movement.
quotes: The implication was that I was closer to God than he was... We know it’s not true.
Paul’s message was shocking in his own time, and it is still shocking today.
Now it is time for us to think about what we want to engrave logizomai on in the 1990s.
strengths: Strong 'upsetting of the equilibrium' regarding religious hierarchy.
Clear movement from the 'then' of Abraham to the 'now' of Grace Church.
Maintains tension by addressing the 'But does this mean we don’t have to do anything?' objection.
improvement_points: The transition to the capital fund drive could be more organically woven into the 'reckoning' theme earlier.
The conclusion could return more explicitly to the 'waterproofing man' to close the narrative loop.
Shorten the middle section on the history of Tuttle Hall to keep the momentum toward the final prayer.
criterion_b1_narrative_arc.plot_diagnosis: A dynamic journey from the 'myth of religious merit' to the 'reality of grace,' though slightly slowed by administrative application.

criterion_b2_integration_text_and_contex.analysis: This is a masterclass in 'Reframing' (Cilliers). The preacher takes a complex Pauline text and reframes the congregation's identity through it. The integration of the 'Father Ritter' scandal and the 'Mother Teresa' idealization provides a sharp, contemporary context that makes the ancient text feel urgent. The sermon does not just 'apply' the text; it uses the text to look at the parish's history (Fitz Allison, Tuttle Hall) and its future (the capital drive). The 'strangeness' of the ungodly being justified is preserved, challenging the hearer's natural inclination toward meritocracy.
quotes: God is just as close to my basement waterproofing man as he is to me.
We have embarked upon a capital fund drive to restore our Federal Buildings... What will we inscribe upon these buildings?
Our modest aspirations in the planning were overtaken and surpassed by God’s providence.
strengths: Excellent use of contemporary 'idols' (Ritter/Teresa) to illustrate the text.
The capital drive is reframed from a 'work' to a 'response to grace'.
The text is allowed to speak into the specific history and 'DNA' of the parish.
improvement_points: The connection between 'reckoning' and 'restoring buildings' could be even more daring—how does a building reflect 'unconditional promise'?
Address more specifically the 'unrighteousness' of the 1990s NYC context beyond the church walls.
Ensure the 'universalist note' mentioned is explored for its aesthetic/spatial implications.
criterion_b2_integration_text_and_contex.reframing_present: The sermon successfully reframes the parish's capital project as an act of grace rather than a meritorious work.

criterion_b3_openness_vs_closedness.analysis: While the sermon is theologically 'open' in its rejection of moralism, the structure itself is somewhat 'closed.' It functions more as a 'Witness' (Long) or a teacher than an 'Open Work of Art' (Stark). The preacher provides the answers and the interpretations quite definitively. There is little room for the hearer to struggle with the text themselves; the 'reckoning' is explained and then applied. The conclusion, while beautiful, is a summary of truths rather than an invitation into a mystery. It is a 'monovalent' sermon that seeks to convince and comfort through a single, powerful interpretation of Romans.
quotes: All of these attitudes are dead wrong... and I use the term 'dead wrong' advisedly.
It is no longer possible to say that Abraham has anything to his credit.
May we all offer our prayers as one prayer.
strengths: The theological clarity provides a 'Space for Grace' that is liberating.
The preacher treats the congregation as mature partners in a theological tradition.
The rejection of moralism opens a space for the 'ungodly' to feel included.
improvement_points: Leave more 'unresolved' questions about what 'reckoning' looks like in the messiness of the 1990s.
Allow for 'resistance'—how does a merit-driven New Yorker feel about 'unearned credit'?
End with a more evocative, open-ended image rather than a summary prayer.
criterion_b3_openness_vs_closedness.open_work_diagnosis: A relatively closed work of art; it is a 'sealed' theological argument, albeit a liberating one.

domain_b_dramaturgy_of_structure.summary_structure: The sermon exhibits a strong narrative arc and exceptional integration of text and context. It moves from a common human misunderstanding (religious hierarchy) to a theological breakthrough (justification by grace). The use of the parish's own history and contemporary scandals makes the 'reframing' of reality palpable. However, the structure is more didactic than 'open,' leaving little room for the hearer's own interpretive play. It is a well-constructed 'journey,' but one where the preacher remains the guide throughout.

kitsch_diagnosis.analysis: The sermon is remarkably free of religious kitsch. It avoids 'pre-chewed' emotions and 'happy endings' that ignore the reality of sin. By mentioning the Father Ritter scandal, the preacher refuses to 'beautify' the church's reality. The definition of grace is not 'sentimental' but 'unromantic' (citing Barth). It does not offer 'immediate comfort' but rather a radical, somewhat jarring 'reckoning' that levels the playing field between the priest and the waterproofing man. This is authentic aesthetic depth that respects the 'pain of the ungodly.'
examples_of_kitsch: The potential kitsch of 'Mother Teresa' is explicitly dismantled by the preacher.
The 'happy ending' of a successful building drive is tempered by the word 'modest aspirations'.
authentic_moments: The admission that clergy find the 'close to God' comment uncomfortable and untrue.
The use of the word 'unromantic' to describe the core of the gospel.
kitsch_diagnosis.recommendation: Continue to lean into the 'unromantic' and 'shocking' nature of grace to prevent the parish's history from becoming a 'pious myth'.

space_for_grace_analysis.analysis: This is the sermon's greatest strength. It is entirely dedicated to 'opening space' for grace. By dismantling the 'idolatry' of religious merit, it creates a vast 'Space for Grace' (Cilliers) where the waterproofing man, the sinner, and the saint stand on equal ground. It sustains the tension between 'ungodliness' and 'righteousness' without resolving it through human effort. The 'mystery' of God's unilateral action is respected and celebrated. It is the antithesis of a moralizing sermon.
space_for_grace_analysis.tension_sustained: The tension between being 'ungodly' and 'reckoned righteous' is the central, sustained theme.
space_for_grace_analysis.mystery_respected: The 'unilateral' and 'unconditional' nature of God's promise is kept as a divine mystery.
space_for_grace_analysis.moralization_vs_grace: Grace prevails absolutely; moralization is explicitly identified as 'dead wrong'.
space_for_grace_analysis.recommendation: To further open space, the preacher could acknowledge the 'silence' of God in the 'reckoning' process—how it feels when we don't feel 'reckoned'.

overall_aesthetics.summary: This sermon is a strong example of 'Sober-Reformed' aesthetics, where the beauty lies in the clarity of the truth and the radicality of the 'reframing.' It avoids the 'visual excess' of flowery rhetoric in favor of a 'stewardship of language' that makes the gospel of grace accessible and urgent. The aesthetic power is found in the 'unromantic' precision of the word 'reckon.' While it lacks the 'openness' of a post-modern work of art, its strength in 'opening space for grace' is exceptional. It successfully bridges the gap between a 1st-century text and a 20th-century urban parish, making the 'holy happen' in the shared realization of common ungodliness and common justification.
strengths_top_3: Radical 'Reframing' of religious hierarchy and parish identity.
Exceptional 'Space for Grace' by dismantling merit-based theology.
Precise 'Stewardship of Language' regarding the term logizomai.
improvement_points_top_3: Increase 'Imagery' in the middle and concluding sections to maintain sensory engagement.
Create more 'Openness' by allowing the congregation to sit with the discomfort of grace.
Smooth the 'Dramaturgical' transition to the administrative capital drive.
overall_aesthetics.comparison_with_specialists: Johan Cilliers (Reframing/Space for Grace) and Thomas Long (Preacher as Witness).
overall_aesthetics.audience_analysis: Intellectually engaged, perhaps merit-driven urban professionals who need the 'unromantic' dismantling of their own self-justification.
recommendations_for_next_sermon: Experiment with 'Show, don't tell' in the application phase.
Use the 'Four Pages' structure to balance the 'trouble' of the city with the 'grace' of the text.
Incorporate more poetic rhythm in the final 'ascription' or prayer.
overall_aesthetics.conclusion: The sermon is an aesthetically effective 'event' that prioritizes the 'beauty of simplicity' and the 'power of metaphor.' It avoids the pitfall of religious kitsch by grounding its hope in the 'unromantic' reality of God's unilateral action. While it leans toward the didactic, its profound success in 'opening space' for the hearer to exist as a 'justified sinner' gives it a lasting aesthetic and theological weight. It is a model of how to handle 'difficult' Pauline theology with contemporary precision.
